answerText: tennis racket theorem[10] The tennis racket theorem can be proven using Euler's equation in the absence of this quantity. This quantity, symbolized tau, is the rotational analogue of force and is divided by moment of inertia to give angular acceleration.

question: Question: Spiegler partly generalized this result to even dimensions using the Arnold energy-Casimir method. For 10 points each: [10] Name this result which states that rotating around the axis with the largest or smallest moment of inertia results in stable rotation, but rotating around the other one results in tumbling.
